prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

head.headtext: Specific factors articulated by the Panel—Potentially conflicting class actions

para.paratext: The Panel has stated that it favors transfer of multiple class actions to a single transferee court in order to facilitate administration of the cases and to prevent potentially conflicting classes. In one early case the Panel stated:

Our experience since [an earlier case] has reinforced our belief that resolution of potentially conflicting class actions are best made by the transferee court …. Such a potential for conflicting or overlapping class actions presents one of the strongest reasons for transferring such related actions to a single district for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings which will include an early resolution of such potential conflicts.[1]

This factor is also discussed in § 5.14. The Panel has also expressed the preference for centralizing potentially competing class actions as favoring conisistency of rulings, “especially with respect to class certification matters.”[2] For the same reasons, potential conflicts between class actions and shareholder derivative actions will also strongly favor transfer.[3]

The reason for the importance of potentially conflicting class actions is fairly clear. The management of the litigation would become exceedingly difficult if similar actions involving overlapping classes were proceeding in different districts.
The Panel's decisions make it clear that multiple class actions will be transferred even if the classes are carefully defined so that no overlap exists. In one case the Panel observed:

While we recognize that the purported classes in the tagalong actions and the previously defined classes in the actions in the transferee district are geographically distinct, Section 1407 proceedings will have the salutary effect of ensuring consistent application of Rule 23.[4]

This factor is a dominating one: if there are conflicting or potentially conflicting class claims in the litigation, transfer is likely regardless of the presence or absence of other factors that would otherwise favor or militate against transfer. There is one situation where the Panel has not automatically ordered transfer of multidistrict cases presenting conflicting class action claims—where there are so few such actions that transfer is not necessary to prevent conflict between the actions.[5] In this situation transfer is not automatic, but is still likely.[6] Similarly, where the Panel finds the actions not sufficiently complex to require transfer, the mere fact there are overlapping class actions will not justify transfer.[7]

Where the class actions are certainly not overlapping, the Panel has been ready to deny transfer.[8] Even where the class actions don't overlap, and multiple parallel single-state class actions have become much more common, the Panel will look to the extent of common fact issues and will frequently order transfer.[9] In one case that underscores how powerful this factor is in favoring transfer, the Panel ordered transfer of class actions with class certification issue but declined to order transfer of related actions that did not include class allegations.[10] Similarly, this factor may prompt the Panel to order transfer for dockets comprising only a few actions.[11] Even non-overlapping class actions can be a factor the Panel mentions in ordering transfer.[12]

The Panel treats potential conflicts in other rulings in a similar way. The Panel has found that centralization also may prevent inconsistent rulings on sovereign immunity and government-contractor liability,[13] patent claim construction,[14] injunctive relief,[15] Daubert issues,[16] and preemption.[17]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

See In re Food Fair Securities Litigation, 465 F. Supp. 1301, 1305 (J.P.M.L. 1979).

See In re Nissan Motor Corp. Antitrust Litigation, 385 F. Supp. 1253 (J.P.M.L. 1974), judgment aff'd, 577 F.2d 910 (5th Cir. 1978), cert. denied, 439 U.S. 1072, 99 S. Ct. 843, 59 L. Ed. 2d 38 (1979); accord In re Initial Public Offering (IPO) Securities Litigation, 277 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (J.P.M.L. 2003) (amendment of pleadings to remove overlap does not eliminate common questions of fact necessary to allow transfer; transfer ordered).

See In re GEICO Telephone Claim Representatives Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) and Wage and Hour Litigation, 223 F. Supp. 3d 1334 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016) (only 2 class, relatively advanced, and minimal overlap cited in denying transfer); In re Royal American Industries, Inc. Securities Litigation, 407 F. Supp. 242, 244 (J.P.M.L. 1976).

See, e.g., In re Toys “R” Us-Delaware, Inc., Fair and Accurate Credit Transactions Act (FACTA) Litigation, 581 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2008) (two actions; transfer ordered); In re Aon Corp. Wage & Hour Employment Practices Litigation, 581 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2008) (two actions, transfer ordered); In re Sulfuric Acid Antitrust Litigation, 270 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2003); In re Clark Oil & Refining Corp. Antitrust Litigation, 364 F. Supp. 458, 459 (J.P.M.L. 1973).
See In re Quaker Oats Maple & Brown Sugar Instant Oatmeal Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 190 F. Supp. 3d 1349 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).

Products Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 609 F. Supp. 2d 1369 (J.P.M.L. 2009) (no overlap of three single-state class actions; transfer denied); In re Hip & Knee Implant Marketing Litigation, 572 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2008) (separate class actions under New York and California state-law classes do not overlap). See also In re: LVNV Funding, LLC, Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA) Litigation, 96 F. Supp. 3d 1374 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015) (transfer denied where “limited overlap” in class actions existed).

See In re Chrysler LLC 2.7 Liter V-6 Engine Oil Sludge Products Liability Litigation, 598 F. Supp. 2d 1372 (J.P.M.L. 2009) (transfer ordered in docket including five overlat); see also In re Lawnmower Engine Horsepower Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation (No. II), 588 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2008) (transfer ordered in docket including 39 known statewide class actions); In re Fresh Dairy Products Antitrust Litigation, 856 F. Supp. 2d 1344 (J.P.M.L. 2012) (no overlap of classes); In re Skinnygirl Margarita Beverage Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 829 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2011) (single-state claims don't overlap).
In re Bank of America Home Affordable Modification Program (HAMP) Contract Litigation, 746 F. Supp. 2d 1359 (J.P.M.L. 2010).
